author: smarlex
title: Glow Formal Verification Stage 2
description: 未经验证的智能合约会导致灾难性的后果：数据泄露、资产损失等。

f6_assessments.q0: The proposal identifies the problem of verifying smart contracts before they get deployed. They will ad value to the Cardano ecosystem by making sure the Dapps that gets created on their language doesn't deploy with faulty smart contracts, which in turn will make for a better user experience. There isn't much metrics to compare to the challenge, but they are building an open source product so it is aligned with the challenge. It would have been beneficial to ad more metrics to the proposal. The project is able to scale well as it will be open source.
f6_assessments.q1: They provided relevant skills and team via Github page. They already have a working product, they just need funding to ad the feature of verifying smart contracts. The budget is for paying salaries for 3 months to 3 software engineers. The time to complete is 3 months which is reasonable. They go into great detail explaining what features will be added to their Glow language. Even how it will address issues when the programmer makes a mistake. They haven't really considered any risks for their project. Not being aware or prepared for future risks can slow you down.
f6_assessments.q2: They haven't provided  a roadmap with milestones for what is being built in the 3 months. Making it hard to track the progress of this project. They also didn't ad any KPIs. Adding user based KPIs like Github downloads and pull requests will enable the community to track the performance of your project. They identify the need to verify smart contracts on their Glow language and they solve this by adding a formal verification engine.

f6_assessments.q0: The use of formal verification will improve the security of the dApps provide assurance in high valued transactions. Open-sourcing the system will help adoption in this all-important security code and will improve adoption. These are core requirements in the Cardano Smart contract constructs and there is a moral obligation for the community to support the development.
f6_assessments.q1: Glow language is expected to simplify contract writing in Cardano and will be released in EVM devnet, The proposal is from the company MuKu which is developing the language. The company has a strategic partnership with IOHK and would have undergone evaluation. Therefore I feel they must be capable of executing the proposal in the best manner.
f6_assessments.q2: The aim of the proposal is to develop three assertions requiring the efforts of three engineers. The steps are clear and can be audited for progress. The success of the proposal is also clearly measurable.

f6_assessments.q0: The problem, the proposers are trying to solve is complex to say the least and absolutely invaluable for future development. It's a verification engine for smart contracts. It fit's the challenge. It is clear that this proposal will greatly benifit but also impact the ecosystem, because of the peace of mind it will give developers when they are running smart contracts and are sure about the correctnes of the logic inside them. Maybe it could have been better articulated because some of the terminology used sure is impressive, but it's not very explanatory. Perhaps a more simple language would go a long way for the next proposals.  The proposer has already been funded and delivered in a previous fund 5, and has managed to scale and grow the project continiously over time, which is kind bility to run a project. One thing I'm missing currently from this proposal is simple explanations. Voters would have a much easier time understanding simple language in the proposal, and tyou can just link a witepaper or other links for the people more interested in the details. This project sure is unique, and it's something Charles Hoskinson has mentioned several times: "WE NEED TOOLS FOR VERIFICATION!". This brings a lot to the table and to the entire cardano developer community. As a developer I don't have any concerns for this proposal, because it seems the team at "Mutual Knowledge Systems" know what they're doing regarding not only the technical implementaion but the project management part as well.

f6_assessments.q2: As I mentioned earlyer, anyone interested in the proposal, can open the site linked in the proposal or go join their discord, which is in my experience, the best way to follow the progress of a project of any type. KPI's weren't mentioned in the proposal and a metric like Usability / downloads per month / linked projects using their infrastructure would have been nice. My recommendation would be to focus on the KPIs as much as they have on the technical part of the proposal, because it's equaly important IMHO. The roadmap is quite clear and the time they've chosen will work out based on what they have already achieved with funding from the previous funds. There is a clear solution to the problem, which is important when you take on such a big challenge.  One suggestion I want to make is for the proposer to put themselves in the shoes of a non-tech-savvy person and read through their proposal, because it's quite hard to read and understand by an every-day-joe.  Excelent proposal, I wish you the best of luck!

f6_assessments.q0:
This project is about making a formal verification engine that helps automated check of programmer's supplied assertions. It solves the problem within the challenge. 
With my developer experiences, I think this project will impact the Cardano ecosystem because it helps the developer a lot.
f6_assessments.q1:
The team behind this project is the team that develop the Glow language and delivered a proof of concept version for Catalyst fund 5. So, I think they can make this project get its goals easily. 
The proposer also provides technical info that can help developers understand how they can customize it. 
But the required budget makes me confused because there is no breakdown info, the proposer only explains the cost for the developer in a month, then asks for the budget which is not related to the previous explained numbers.
f6_assessments.q2:
The proposer does not provide enough info that's sufficient to audit the progress and the success of this project. He has no detailed roadmap, and no key metrics, they're the basic things for auditing the project. 
However, the proposer has a good awareness of the problem and explains well how this project can help to solve that. But I hope that he can discover some risks on the plan then show here in the proposal.
